subject: RE: [junit] How to record test results in XML format
msgSnippet: First, you did not read the error message: If I commented Out taskdef and use test tag I ... Please download optional.jar from the Ant web site and place it in
messageBody:
First, you did not read the error message:

If I commented Out taskdef and use test tag I
>am getting "/users/test/build.xml:10: Could not create
>task of type: junit. Common solutions are to use
>taskdef to declare your task, or, if this is an
>optional task, to put the optional.jar in the lib
>directory of your ant installation (ANT_HOME)".

Please download optional.jar from the Ant web site and place it in
${ANT_HOME}\lib.

Also, please ensure that the .jar/.class file(s) containing your task
are in ${ANT_HOME}\lib when you attempt to run your task.

And finally, if you have further problems with this, please direct them
to the Ant user mailing list, since this is not a JUnit problem.
Someone there will be more than happy to help you.

Good luck.

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********

On 2002-07-10 at 12:51 syed Anwaruddin wrote:

>Hi,
>Thanks for the immediate reply!!!
>
>I have been trying this since yesterday without any
>break through...
>
>I modified my build.xml file. Following below is the
>snippet:
><project name="Autotest" default="run">
> <!-- taskdef name="myrun"
>classname="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness" -->
> <!-- classpath -->
> <!-- pathelement
>location="/vobs/autotest/portal_kernel/lib/junit.jar"
>/-->
> <!-- pathelement
>location="/ausp3/jakarta-ant-1.4.1/lib/optional.jar"/-->
> <!-- /classpath -->
> <!-- taskdef -->
>
> <target name="run">
> <junit printsummary="true">
> <test
>name="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness"
>outfile="results" >
> <formatter type="xml" />
> </test>
> </junit>
> </target>
>
></project>
>
>If I define the taskdef I am getting error as
>"com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness" class not
>found. If I commented Out taskdef and use test tag I
>am getting "/users/test/build.xml:10: Could not create
>task of type: junit. Common solutions are to use
>taskdef to declare your task, or, if this is an
>optional task, to put the optional.jar in the lib
>directory of your ant installation (ANT_HOME)".
>
>Please help me in resolving this. I am new to ANT and
>did'nt know how to resolve it. I even copied
>junit.jar, src.jar to my AN_HOME/lib directory. Even
>this did'nt resolve the issue.
>
>Thanks in Advance!!!
>Syed.
>
>
>
>
>--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>wrote:
>> Impossible. The error can't happen if the <taskdef>
>> tag is commented
>> out. Either try again or tell us that line 2 should
>> not be commented
>> out.
>>
>> Thanks.
>>
>> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>>

>> >

>> ><project name="Autotest" default="run">
>> > <!-- taskdef name="myrun"
>> >classname="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness"
>> -->
>> > <classpath>
>> > <pathelement
>>
>>location="/vobs/autotest/portal_kernel/lib/junit.jar"
>> >/>
>> > <pathelement
>>
>>location="/ausp3/jakarta-ant-1.4.1/lib/optional.jar"
>> >/>
>> > </classpath>
>> > </taskdef>
>> >
>> > <target name="run">
>> > <junit printsummary="true">
>> > <test
>> >name="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness"
>> >outfile="results">
>> > <formatter type="xml"
>> />
>> > </test>
>> > </junit>
>> > </target>
>> >
>> ></project>
>> >
>> >
>> >Please help me in resolving this issue.
>> >
>> >Note: I am using Jbuilder to build my class file
>> then
>> >I am using ANT to run the class and output the
>> result
>> >in XML format.
>> >
>> >Thanks in Advance!!!!
>> >
>> >Regards,
>> >Syed.
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>> >wrote:
>> >> Likely you do not have Ant's "optional.jar" in
>> the
>> >> CLASSPATH when
>> >> running Ant. Please refer to the Ant
>> documentation
>> >> for details.

>> >> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>> >>
>> >> On 2002-07-09 at 14:23 syed Anwaruddin wrote:
>> >>
>> >> >Hi Jason,
>> >> >
>> >> >Thanks for your help!!!!
>> >> >
>> >> >When I execute sample build.xml, I am getting
>> the
>> >> >following error:
>> >> >"Unexpected element "junit"
>> >> >
>> >> >Following below is the sample code:
>> >> ><project name="Autotest" default="test">
>> >> > <target name="run" />
>> >> > <junit printsummary="true" >
>> >> > <test
>> >> >name="com.test.tc.autotest.checkClass"
>> >> >outfile="results">
>> >> > <formatter type="xml" />
>> >> > </test>
>> >> > </junit>
>> >> >
>> >> ></project>
>> >> >
>> >> >Please let me know where I am wrong.
>> >> >
>> >> >Thanks & Regards,
>> >> >Syed.
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> >--- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...>
>> wrote:
>> >> >> go to http://jakarta.apache.org/ant
>> >> >> download a binary (which includes
>> documentation)
>> >> >> set up your build script (read the
>> documentation)
>> >> >> run it (read the documentation)
>> >> >>
>> >> >> A simple build script may be (you'll want to
>> >> replace
>> >> >> all the hardcoded
>> >> >> paths to properties):
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <project name="MyProject" default="tests">
>> >> >> <path id="somePath">
>> >> >> <pathelement
>> location="lib/sub1/some1.jar"/>
>> >> >> <pathelement
>> location="lib/sub2/some2.jar"/>
>> >> >> <pathelement
>> location="lib/sub3/some3.jar"/>
>> >> >> </path>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <target name="tests" depends="build">
>> >> >> <junit printsummary="yes"
>> haltonfailure="no">
>> >> >> <classpath refid="somePath"/>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <formatter type="xml"/>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <batchtest fork="yes" todir="reports">
>> >> >> <fileset dir="build"/>
>> >> >> </batchtest>
>> >> >> </junit>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <junitreport todir="reports">
>> >> >> <fileset dir="reports">
>> >> >> <include name="TEST-*.xml"/>
>> >> >> </fileset>
>> >> >> <report format="frames"
>> todir="reports"/>
>> >> >> </junitreport>
>> >> >> </target>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> <target name="build">
>> >> >> <javac
>> >> >> srcdir="src"
>> >> >> destdir="build">
>> >> >> <classpath refid="somePath"/>
>> >> >> </javac>
>> >> >> </target>
>> >> >> </project>
>> >> >> On Tue, 2002-07-09 at 09:37, syed Anwaruddin
>> >> wrote:
>> >> >> Hi Scott,
>> >> >>
>> >> >> Thanks for the immediate reply!!!
>> >> >>
>> >> >> You mean, I need to install ANT module???
>> >> >> I am very new to this. Please mail me one
>> example
>> >> OR
>> >> >> atleast let me know where can I find the
>> >> >> documentation
>> >> >> for this.
>> >> >>
>> >> >> Thanks and Regards,
>> >> >> Syed.
>> >> >>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> --- Scott Stirling <scottstirling@...>
>> wrote:
>> >> >> > Easiest way to do it is use the JUnit tasks
>> >> >> (<junit>
>> >> >> > and <batchtest>) in
>> >> >> > Ant, which will automatically output results
>> in
>> >> >> XML
>> >> >> > format if you tell
>> >> >> > them to. Then use <junitreport> to
>> >> automatically
>> >> >> > transform the XML into
>> >> >> > a nice framed HTML report.
>> >> >> >
>> >> >> > Scott Stirling
>> >> >> >
>> >> >> > > -----Original Message-----
>> >> >> > > From: s_thoda [mailto:s_thoda@...]
>>
